text:
You know this already. You're smart and have probably noticed it too. I think the start of your issues began when you left university. You can’t just sit around doing nothing. Getting a job and having a clear goal could really help you out. 

“Yeah, you’re totally right… I’ll rush back to the university, and then everything will be fine…” 

Zossimov, who was trying to sound wise (and impress the ladies), was caught off guard when he saw a smirk on Raskolnikov’s face. It was quick, though. Pulcheria Alexandrovna jumped in, thanking Zossimov, especially for visiting them the night before. 

“What? He saw you last night?” Raskolnikov said, looking surprised. “So you didn’t sleep after your trip?”

“Oh, Rodya, we were up until two. Dounia and I never sleep before then at home.” 

“I don’t even know how to thank him,” Raskolnikov said, suddenly frowning and looking down. “Forget about payment—sorry to bring it up (he glanced at Zossimov)—but I really don’t get why you’re giving me so much attention! It’s confusing, honestly, and it’s kind of stressing me out.” 

“Don’t get worked up,” Zossimov said, forcing a laugh. “Just think of me as your first patient—well, we all just…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov contemplates the importance of having a purpose and occupation to aid his mental state after leaving the university.
